content.summary_of_the_paper:
This paper study an interesting problem that improves user engagement in sequential recommendations. Considering that current rules of taking a break are manually settled, this paper propose to learning a user dependent and stationary policy to decide when to take a break.
Lotka-Volterra dynamics is used to model two patterns of users, drive to consume and intrinsic interest. 

A learning algorithm based this dynamics is proposed and is validated on a semi-synthetic public data.
content.strength_and_weaknesses:
Strength:

1.The problem of when to take a break is important and interesting for recommendation.

2.The theoretical analysis of Lotka-Volterra dynamics is quite novel.

3.The performance improvement as reported in Figure 3 is significant.

Weakness:

1.This paper aim to learn a policy that is independent of time step, which might limits the performance.

2.This paper assumes that the behavior flows the Lotka-Volterra dynamics. Does the authors justify the assumption in real datasets?

3.What is the detail of the evaluation metric? There is no engagement metric in MoiveLens.

content.summary_of_the_paper: The paper investigates how to promote digital well-being through individualized breaking policies. They propose a disciplined learning framework for responsible and sustainable optimization of long-term user engagement. For user behavior simulation, they utilize Lokta-Volterra (LV) dynamical systems to depict users as acting based on two balancing forces: drive to consume and intrinsic interest. The simulation is novel but lack of experimental verification. Finally, the paper proposes an efficient learning algorithm and evaluate it on semi-synthetic data.
content.strength_and_weaknesses:
#Strength
1. The paper studies recommendation systems as human-centric ecosystems, and take one step towards sustainable design. This provides a new perspective on viewing recommender systems.  
2. The paper proposes to model user behavior as a dynamical system of Lotka-Volterra (LV) Predator-Prey equations to optimize engagement with breaks, where the effect of break policies is modeled by control variables. Such design is ingenious and innovative.

#Weakness
1. The paper needs to further explain the rationality of introducing LV dynamic systems. Under this model, the paper proposes two latent variables and analyzes their dynamical properties. There should be some online experimental results (e.g. A/B test) to verify the existence of such hidden variables and the dynamical properties of latent variables. Modeling the time-dependent relations as in Equation (2) seems not very convincing to me.
2. The experiment description is not clear enough. 
3. The experimental results are not sufficient. It would be much better to conduct online evaluation or offline evaluation on more semi-synthetic datasets.
4. The overall paper also needs an additional round of writing revision.
Grammar Error:
1)	In section 1 “To be preemtive” -> “To be preemptive”
2)	In section 1  “with the persceince” -> ““with the prescience”
3)	In section 1.1 “types of feedfback” ->  “types of feedback”

content.summary_of_the_paper: In this paper the authors study how recommenders could provide a personalized approach to recommending breaks to users that would still maximize long-term engagements.  The authors do this by assuming a particular dynamic model of user interest (Lotka-Volterra) and demonstrating how a policy could be learned for recommending breaks to users in conjunction with a recommender system.  They test this on simulated user dynamics on top of Movielens ratings data to demonstrate that their learned policy is more effective than alternative approaches.
content.strength_and_weaknesses:
S1. The question of how to better incorporate user well being into recommender design and how we can leverage long term models to do so is an interesting and important question to study.
S2. Under the assumed model given, the paper is thorough in exploring the learning problem and demonstrating the efficacy of their learning approach.

W1. The assumed model of user dynamic is highly novel - this is a strength in that it has not been used in the recommender literature before (as far as I know) but the paper does not actually explain or demonstrate why this particular model is a good one.  The experiments do show that it is flexible for learning even assuming a more complex user model, but alternative framings of the problem (e.g. from Kleinberg et al 2022) are not compared with and no empirical evidence is given that this fits or benefits real users at all.

W2. The paper does not consider a lot of recent work and important aspects of recommender systems related to the actual items being recommended.  There is a large body of literature on diversity, dynamics of user interests within and across topics, additional signals of user feedback and satisfaction, leveraging surveys, etc.  In addition to not well contextualizing this work, this  both under-leverages state-of-the-art approaches for understanding user well being and is a limitation of the assumed user model, e.g. where user interest is unidimensinoal rather than evolving across many dimensions.
content.clarity,_quality,_novelty_and_reproducib:
Clarity: The paper is relatively easy to read and the main ideas are clearly described.

Quality: The paper makes some strong assumptions in their problem framing that are in my opinion not sufficiently supported, but under those assumptions the paper is thorough in studying how to incorporate them into the recommender design and evaluating their methods' effectiveness.

Novetly: The question being studied and the model deployed is novel and I think would be of interest to other researchers.

Reproducibility: While I don't believe code is provided, I expect the methods could be reproduced.
content.summary_of_the_review: Overall, the paper is thorough in exploring a novel design space for recommender systems.  However, I believe significant additional research would be needed to demonstrate that their assumed dynamics model is reflective of real users and that their proposed approach does lead to higher long term user satisfaction.  As a result, I do not believe the paper is ready for publication at ICLR.
